none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from Sims (), December 14, 1885
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from Sims (), December 14, 1885
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 21 Louis L. McInnis Papers

en: A letter from C. W. James of the Panhandle National Bank in Wichita Falls, Texas to Professor Louis L. McInnis regarding the purchase of bank stock. James outlines the bank's financial strategy, capital structure, projected dividends, and business growth, while also inviting McInnis to invest in bank shares and discussing land colonization efforts in the Panhandle region. The letter includes personal remarks about family matters, including the death of James's sister, and extends social regards to McInnis and his wife.

body.value:
CAPITAL $ 50,000. No. 3200. AUTHORIZED CAPITAL $ 200,000.

Panhandle National Bank

JOHN G. JAMES Prest
ASHBY S. JAMES, Cashier.
W. A. KNOTT. Vice Prest

All branches of Conservative Banking carefully conducted.
Special attention given collections and investments in the Panhandle.

NEAREST NATIONAL BANK TO
MOBEETIE SEYMOUR, ARCHER VERNON, CLARENDON,
PEASE CITY AND ALL PANHANDLE POINTS.

Accounts of Stockmen, Land-Dealers, Merchants and other business men respectfully solicited.

CORRESPONDENTS.

| | | | :--- | :--- | | HANOVER NATIONAL BANK | NEW YORK. | | VALLEY NATIONAL BANK | ST. LOUIS. | | BALL, HUTCHINGS & CO. | GALVESTON. |

Wichita Falls, Tex. Decr 14 1885

Prof L. L. McInnis.

Dear Sir: your letter duly to hand – am
sorry to hear of your injury to your hand, but
hope it is entirely well by now.

In regard to Bank-stock. Will be pleased to
have you take the $ 500 or $ 1000, as may suit
you, and will at any rate reserve the $ 1000
for you until after Jany 15th /86. We are now
having the stock rapidly engaged, and before
Feby 1, the maximum am't stock intended to
be issued will doubtless have been issued.
$ 100 00000 Capital is all we now contemplate
issuing for years, if we ever issue more.
Our policy will be to hold the capital at that
figure and steadily increase (from profits) the

First, I analyzed the request, noting my role as a transcriptionist and the need to preserve spelling, punctuation, and reading order, interpreting handwriting carefully. I must use layout indicators, structural element labels, and specific HTML tags to render the final transcript. I then examined the image itself. I also noted the handwritten date "Wichita Falls, Tex. Decr 14 1885," the addressee "Prof L. L. McInnis," and the 19th-century cursive handwriting style. The content of the letter discusses "Bank-stock" details, financial amounts, dates, and future capital plans. Decr 14 1885 * The salutation: Prof L. L. McInnis. Dear Sir: * The Body: I'll transcribe each paragraph carefully, accounting for potential scrawls, such as: "your letter duly to hand – am sorry to hear of your injury to your hand, but hope it is entirely well by now. In regard to Bank-stock. Will be pleased to have you take the $ 500 or $ 1000, as may suit you, and will at any rate reserve the $ 1000 for you until after Jany 15th /86. We are now having the stock rapidly engaged, and before Feby 1, the maximum am't stock intended to be issued will doubtless have been issued. $ 100 00000 Capital is all we now contemplate issuing for years, if we ever issue more. Our policy will be to hold the capital at that figure and steadily increase (from profits) the" I am ready to produce the transcription now.

Surplus, until it reaches $100 000 also. We will, therefore,
pay only 6% semi annual dividends, for some years to
come, and carry all rest of profits to Surplus
Fund. This of course belongs to stock-holders.
We will net Jany 1. about 9% for the six
months, and the stock, after dividends are
paid will be worth between 103 & 104 - I will
agree now to put it, though, at 103 for you.
I feel reasonably sure that the stock will net
not less than 20% in next twelve months - and
as Surplus increases, and we compound the profits,
the stock will annually do better and better.

We are having a very fine business now,
our line of customers steadily increasing, and
our deposits have gone up to near $80 000.
Have sold considerable stock to friends in Houston &
Galveston - Expect to sell $5000 or more Jany 1. to
young Mr. Ball, of Ball, Hutchings & Co. He came
up to see us a few days since, & was much pleased.

In remitting, if you send Galveston, Houston, Austin, F.W.
Dallas, New York or St Louis, we can use at
par for you. Expect you can now get N.Y.
in Bryan at par, on acct of cotton Exchange being so
large. We have now all except about $15000 stock
placed, & I am sure my Eastern stock holders will
take it all after January. Bringhurst spoke of taking
some stock this winter - / If you see Jasper, you might
give him the substance of this letter. The stock once

JAMES Prest                                                 W. A. KNOTT, Vice Prest                                                 ASHBY S. JAMES, Cashier. [Map: PANHANDLE OF TEXAS, INDIAN TERRITORY, NEW MEXICO] All branches of Conservative Banking carefully conducted. Special attention given collections and investments in the Panhandle. NEAREST NATIONAL BANK TO MOBEETIE SEYMOUR, ARCHER VERNON, CLARENDON, PEASE CITY AND ALL PANHANDLE POINTS. Accounts of Stockmen, Land-Dealers, Merchants and other business men respectfully solicited. CORRESPONDENTS. | | | | :--- | :--- | | HANOVER NATIONAL BANK | NEW YORK. | | VALLEY NATIONAL BANK | ST. LOUIS. | | BALL, HUTCHINGS & CO. | GALVESTON. |
Wichita Falls, Tex. ___________________ 188 issued, is going to be very hard to get, and at high figure. This country is getting a large stream of immigration now, and our county will quadruple its farmers this coming winter. Lands selling briskly. Since you were here I have become interested in two large bodies of land, which we are now trying to colonize. One is 18000 acres on Red River, and I am now putting families on it, having it cut into 160 acre farms. The other is 3 miles from town in Wichita Valley, 7000 acres. We hope to settle them in next two years, & will I believe make something out of them. Our family has been made sad by the death

CAPITAL $ 50,000. No.

of my sister Betty, who died Nov 27. of
consumption - the disease culminating in a
profuse hemorrhage which carried her off.
She was buried at Weatherfd beside her
husband, my eldest brother. I never saw
a purer more consistent Christian life,
and her sufferings, which were great, were
borne with the greatest cheerfulness and
resignation. We feel that she is far better off,
and as much as we regret her departure, we
cannot wish her back again to all the suffering
she had to bear.

Had letter yesterday from Cole - he was in
good spirits - expects to visit Sherman Xmas.
will not come by here.

I hope you are getting along pleasantly at
the College, and that matters in general are
prospering.

My wife has been confined to her bed some days
but is better now. She unites with me in
best wishes & regards for yourself and Mrs
McL.

you can remit for the $500 stock now, or after
Jany 1. as may best suit your convenience
Yrs sincerely Ch. W. James

**Finalizing the Transcription: A Thought Process** Alright, let's get this done. The task is to transcribe this handwritten letter, preserving its original formatting, spelling, and using the specified HTML tags – nothing fancy, just pure, accurate transcription. I'm seeing a mid-19th to early 20th-century cursive style, dark ink on aged paper. This is a personal letter – dealing with a recent death, funeral plans, a letter from someone named "Cole," and some personal and financial matters. First, I'm working through each line, carefully analyzing the handwriting. Context is key! "Died Nov 27" – looks solid. "Consumption" – yep, tuberculosis. Euphemisms, like "carried her off," are typical for the era. The trickiest part is always place names and names. "Weathersfd" – hmm. It *looks* like that, maybe "Weathersfield," but I'm sticking to what's visible. I'll need to recheck that one. The husband/brother relationship is a little confusing – it *could* imply incest, but given the time, it's more likely a brother-in-law or even an appositive. I'll stick with what's written. Spelling is generally good, but I'm checking every letter, especially any ambiguous ones. I'm making a note of any questionable words and going back to refine them. I am going to double-check "Weatherfd". And the "McL." or "McC." abbreviation is a bit unclear, but based on the context, "McL." seems the most likely. The signature is tricky as well. Is it "H" or "W"? It is more like "W" as the writer writes the letter. I am checking "now" and confirm it. Formatting is next. Preserving the line breaks using `

`. I've drafted the entire text, going back again to check. "Weatherfd" is still the issue. It's written "Weatherfd". And "Cole" and "Sherman" are readable. The "McL" at the end looks like "McL", not anything else. Double-checking "Betty" (line 1), "Jany" (line 24), "remit" (line 23), "$500" (line 23). The text is well done. The alignment of the "Yrs" and the signature are important to preserve. I am finalizing the transcription. Now checking the name abbreviations. The "McL." is probably it. "Weatherfd" is what is written. Signature: "Ch. W. James" - the W is clear. The indentation is good. The text flow is correct. Everything is very clear now. I can verify each word.
